graph

Class Graph<V,E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • graph.Graph<V,E>
  • Type Parameters:
    V - Generic type representing vertices
    E - Generic type representing edges
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SimpleGraph

    public class Graph<V,E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    Represents a Graph - a relational data structure. All relations of which vertices possess which edges, etc are maintained internally within the Graph to fully encapsulate the data structure.

    The only main requirement made on use of the Graph class is that every vertex and edge that is stored within the graph needs to be a *unique* instance of V and E, respectively. This is due to the use of HashMaps for storage, thus multiple edges can't be created from the same E instance.
    Author:
    Mshnik

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Graph()
      Constructs a new graph that contains no vertices or edges and is directed - Calls Graph(true)
      Graph(boolean directed)
      Constructs a new graph that contains no vertices or edges
      Graph(Graph<? extends V,? extends E> g)
      Constructs a new graph that is a copy of the given graph The two graphs contain the same elements but are completely independent in terms of underlying structure, so modifications to this Graph won't alter the returned graph, and modifications to the returned graph won't alter this graph.

      However, the graph is shallowly copied - V and E instances are not copied - they will be contained in both this graph and g.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Graph

        public Graph(boolean directed)
        Constructs a new graph that contains no vertices or edges
        Parameters:
        directed - - true if this is a graph of directed edges, false otherwise

      • Graph

        public Graph()
        Constructs a new graph that contains no vertices or edges and is directed - Calls Graph(true)

      • Graph

        public Graph(Graph<? extends V,? extends E> g)
        Constructs a new graph that is a copy of the given graph The two graphs contain the same elements but are completely independent in terms of underlying structure, so modifications to this Graph won't alter the returned graph, and modifications to the returned graph won't alter this graph.

        However, the graph is shallowly copied - V and E instances are not copied - they will be contained in both this graph and g. If deep copy behavior is necessary for V or E, extend graph re-write this constructor.

    • Method Detail

      • clone

        public Graph<V,E> clone()
        Returns a new Graph that is a copy of this. The two graphs contain the same elements but are completely independent in terms of underlying structure, so modifications to this Graph won't alter the returned graph, and modifications to the returned graph won't alter this graph.

        However, the graph is shallowly copied - V and E instances are not copied - they will be contained in both this graph and g. If deep copy behavior is necessary for V or E, extend graph and overwrite this method.
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object

      • unmodifiableGraph

        public Graph<V,E> unmodifiableGraph()
        Returns a new Graph that is an unmodifiable view of this.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
        Two graphs are equivalent if they store the same vertices and edges, and are the same directionality (both directed, or both undirected)
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object

        public int hashCode()
        Hashes a Graph based on its vertices, edges, and directed-ness
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object

      • vertexSet

        public java.util.Set<V> vertexSet()
        Returns a Set of the vertices in this graph. This set is a copy of the underlying keyset, so it is pass by value. Altering the returned set will not affect the graph.

        public boolean containsVertex(V v)
        Returns true iff this graph contains the given vertex.

        Returns the number of vertices in this graph

      • edgeSet

        public java.util.Set<E> edgeSet()
        Returns a Set of the edges in this graph. This set is a copy of the underlying keyset, so it is pass by value. Altering the returned set will not affect the graph.

      • containsEdge

        public boolean containsEdge(E e)
        Returns true iff this graph contains the edge E

      • edgeSize

        public int edgeSize()
        Returns the number of edges in this graph

      • isDirected

        public boolean isDirected()
        Returns whether or not this graph is directed. If this graph is undirected, all edges are treated as bi-directional for the purposes of directed-graph algorithms.

      • addVertex

        public boolean addVertex(V v)
        Adds the given vertex to the graph with no edges. If the vertex is already in the graph, do nothing and return false Returns true if the an operation is performed this way, false otw.

      • addEdge

        public boolean addEdge(V source,
                       V sink,
                       E e)
                throws NotInCollectionException
        Connects the two given vertices in the graph by adding an edge. If there is already a connection from source to sink (or sink to source and this is undirected), or e is already an edge in this graph, do nothing and return false. Returns true if an operation is performed this way, false otw.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - - if source or sink are not vertices in this graph

      • removeVertex

        public boolean removeVertex(V v)
        Removes this vertices (And all of the edges going in and out of it) from the graph. Returns true if the vertex was removed this way, false if there was no vertex to remove.

      • removeEdge

        public boolean removeEdge(E e)
        Removes this edge from the graph. Returns true if the edge was removed this way, false if there was no edge to remove.

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Clears this graph entirely, removing all edges and vertices.

      • getConnection

        public E getConnection(V source,
                       V sink)
                throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the edge with the given source and sink, if any. Returns null if there is no such edge. For undirected graphs, returns any edge that connects the two, in either direction
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - - if source or sink are not vertices in this graph

      • isConnected

        public boolean isConnected(V source,
                           V sink)
                    throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns true iff there is an edge with the given source and sink. For undirected graphs, returns true iff there is any edge that connects the two, in either direction.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - - if source or sink are not vertices in this graph

      • getOther

        public V getOther(E e,
                  V oneEnd)
           throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the vertex at the other end of the given edge. Returns null if oneEnd is neither end of e.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if e isn't an edge in this graph

             throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the number of edges with the given vertex as an endpoint (source or sink)
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if v is not in this graph

      • edgeSetOfSource

        public java.util.Set<E> edgeSetOfSource(V source)
                                 throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns a set of all edges with v as a source. If this graph is undirected returns edgeSetOf(source) instead, as every vertex is source and sink
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if source is not in this graph

      • outDegreeOf

        public int outDegreeOf(V source)
                throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the number of edges with the given vertex as an source. If this graph is undirected, returns degreeOf(source) instead, as every vertex is a source and sink.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if v is not in this graph

      • edgeSetOfSink

        public java.util.Set<E> edgeSetOfSink(V sink)
                               throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns a set of all edges with v as a sink. If this graph is undirected returns edgeSetOf(source) instead, as every vertex is source and sink
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if sink is not in this graph

      • inDegreeOf

        public int inDegreeOf(V sink)
               throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the number of edges with the given vertex as an sink. If this graph is undirected, returns degreeOf(sink) instead, as every vertex is a source and sink.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if v is not in this graph

      • sourceOf

        public V sourceOf(E e)
           throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the source of the given edge. If this is undirected, returns the first endpoint - the endpoint given first when the edge was created.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if e is not in this graph

      • sinkOf

        public V sinkOf(E e)
         throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the sink of the given edge. If this is undirected, returns a second endpoint - the endpoint given second when the edge was created.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if e is not in this graph

      • verticesOf

        public java.util.List<V> verticesOf(E e)
                             throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the vertices on either end of the given edge - a List of length 2 The returned list is read-only - attempts to modify it will cause an UnsupportedOperationException.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if e is not in this graph

      • isSelfEdge

        public boolean isSelfEdge(E e)
                   throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns true if the given edge is a self edge - two endpoints are the same vertex, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if e is not in this graph

      • isEndpointOf

        public boolean isEndpointOf(E e,
                            V endpoint)
                     throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns true iff v is one endpoint of e, false otherwise
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException - if e is not in this graph

      • getSharedEndpoint

        public V getSharedEndpoint(E e1,
                           E e2)
                    throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns the shared endpoint between the two edges. If both endpoints are shared, an arbitrary endpoint is returned. If they do not share an endpoint, returns null
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException

      • neighborsOf

        public java.util.Set<V> neighborsOf(V v)
                             throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns all neighbor vertices to v. In a directed graph this is the set of vertices a in A for which there exists an edge e with v as the source and a as the sink. In an undirected graph, this is the set of vertices for which there exists an edge e with v as either the source or the sink and a as the other endpoint.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException

      • sharedNeighborsOf

        public java.util.Set<V> sharedNeighborsOf(V v1,
                                          V v2)
                                   throws NotInCollectionException
        Returns all vertices that are shared neighbors of v1 and v2.
        Throws:
        NotInCollectionException
